I believe we need to be clear about this, that it is for a short period. I personally would not support an extension of time on that reference, if the committee were to seek it. The reference would be for such a short period that undoubtedly we would be able to vote yet again on the Government's Bill prior to the next election. I believe that those of us who are opposed to the retrospective element ought to have the opportunity to cast our votes that way before the next election so that the people of Australia know where everyone clearly stands on these issues. I am happy to go to the people yet again on the fact that I have stood firmly by a principle I believe in, and I will do so again in the future.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tate

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw attention to the fact that the Senate has before it at the moment a Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to income tax, which is entitled: 'Private Senator 's Bill-Senator Jack Evans'. I raise the point that in fact it may be that this Bill ought not to originate in the Senate under the provisions of section 53 of the Constitution. The fact is that there has been a long tradition in parliaments, in their relationship with the Executive in the Westminster tradition, which is to the effect that the financial initiative lies with the Crown, which can be translated in Australian Constitutional terms as to say that the Executive, which is composed of those members of the Executive Council who enjoy the confidence of the majority of members of the House of Representatives, has the constitutional responsibility for introducing laws into this Parliament which impose taxation on the Australian community or, on the other side, appropriate revenue or moneys for its expenditures. That tradition is carried into effect in section 53 of our Constitution, the first sentence of which reads :

INTERJECT.PARA: Proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys, or imposing taxation, shall not originate in the Senate.

When one looks at this private member's Bill introduced into the Senate by Senator Jack Evans one sees, as I said, that its long title is 'A Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to income tax'. In its operative provisions I believe that it imposes a tax on certain benefits received from or in connection with certain superannuation funds, which tax did not exist before. In other words, it creates a liability in relation to those benefits received from or in connection with superannuation funds, which liability did not exist before.

I believe that the mere fact that the Bill seeks to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act should not mislead us into thinking that this amending Bill deals merely with assessment matters. I believe it imposes a tax. The Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, which is sought to be amended, in fact in its long title is entitled 'An Act to consolidate and amend the Law relating to the Imposition, Assessment and Collection of a Tax upon incomes'. It is recognised there that the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 does indeed contain provisions and is intended, amongst other things, to have provisions relating to the imposition of a tax upon incomes. I believe that in this provision we are dealing with such an imposition of a tax. Therefore, it is a Bill which ought not to originate in the Senate.

It is true that Parliamentary Counsel has appended the notation 'T' at the bottom of the first page of the Government's Bill on the same matter, which is taken to be his categorisation of the Bill as a measure not imposing taxation, but in this regard I do not think the Senate chamber can be absolutely bound by the opinion of Parliamentary Counsel. I point out that if the Chair rules that this is not a Bill to impose taxation, it has, I believe, serious consequences for the Senate because it means, for example, in relation to section 55 of the Constitution that other matters could be tacked on to this sort of Bill coming into the Senate chamber. I raise the point of order and seek your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President, as to whether, in fact, this private member's Bill can originate in the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Jack Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order that has been raised is very interesting. I imagine that the Minister for Energy and Resources (Senator Walsh) is in a great state of confusion at the moment because, if the point of order is upheld, the whole basis of retrospective legislation falls to the ground. This is because the grounds for all these Bills-the bottom of the harbour legislation and the 23F legislation we are currently considering-has been on the foundation stone that the taxes were already in existence and that the Bills were simply machinery items to ensure that the taxes were collected. The Bill that I have put forward, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1984, is simply a machinery provision. It provides for the assessment of a tax. It does not impose a new tax. It simply ensures that the Commissioner of Taxation has the powers to collect a tax which is already provided for under existing legislation. I draw your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, to page 390 of Odgers's 'Australian Senate Practice' which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Machinery Acts for the assessment and collection of taxes, such as the Income Tax Assessment Act, and Customs Act, are not deemed by the Senate to be laws imposing taxation and, accordingly, are amendment Bills. If machinery clauses were included in the Bills which imposed the taxes, the effect would be to take from the Senate its power to amend such machinery clauses, because the Senate cannot amend proposed laws imposing taxation.

In 1923 an Income Tax Assessment Bill was originated in the Senate by a private member. Upon a Minister taking a point of order, President Givens ruled that the Bill did not come within the category of those which cannot be originated in the Senate, and he ruled that the Bill was not out of order. This ruling confirmed an earlier ruling by President Givens in 1921 that an Income Tax Assessment Bill can originate in the Senate.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to rule similarly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks that have just been made by Senator Jack Evans. I was surprised that Senator Tate raised the matter. I was surprised when he first quoted section 53 of the Constitution and made no reference to section 55, because undoubtedly this Bill is a machinery provision providing for the assessment of a tax and not for the imposition of a tax. The quotation from Mr Odgers's book clearly establishes the Senate's practice with regard to these Bills and the established nature of them. If, under section 55, the Government intended that this should be a Bill imposing taxation, it should not have included other matters in the Bill which change the nature of the Bill to a Bill that is an assessment Bill and thus capable of being amended in the Senate and dealt with in the way we have established over a number of years. I uphold what has been said by Senator Jack Evans. As I have said earlier, I commend his Bill to the Senate as one that follows matters we are able to support. I think that what has been raised by Senator Tate is clearly not a point of order in dealing with the legislation before us.
—Mr Acting Deputy President--
—Senator Harradine, I have heard three speakers on this point of order. I will now rule on it.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your indulgence to speak to the point of order as the Minister present.
—The problem I have is that honourable senators will be speaking all the time on the point of order. If I allow you to speak, I shall have to allow Senator Harradine to do likewise.
—In that case, I observe that I shall make some comments when I speak on the Bill.

—There is no point of order. I have been advised that Bills for the assessment and collection of taxes have always been treated separately from Bills imposing taxation. They have always been treated as Bills which can be introduced into the Senate and can be amended by the Senate. This practice has the explicit support of the Parliamentary Counsel, who in this particular case, as with all other government assessment Bills, has marked the Government's Bill as dealing with taxation and not imposing taxation. I have no grounds to disagree with that practice. While Senator Tate has raised some interesting points, I cannot rule on constitutional practices. Therefore, there is no point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, can I just clarify your ruling? Are you saying that you cannot rule on constitutional practices and therefore do not uphold my point of order, or that in substance you reject my argument?
—No. I am saying that in substance the argument is rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am due to speak anyway, I would like to make a couple of comments on this matter . I think that Senator Tate has raised a very important question. I have taken note of the points that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and other speakers have made. But whatever legal obfuscation may be able to excuse or justify, I think it is an indisputable fact that the introduction of a Bill such as the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 into the Senate breaches the spirit of the Constitution.
—What do you mean by that?

—Let me go on to explain. I am aware of the distinction which has been drawn in the past between the principle of taxing assessable income and those guideline or laws which define assessable income. Nevertheless, the practical effect of Senator Jack Evans's Bill, without any doubt whatsoever, will be to make certain people liable to taxation to which they were not previously liable because the provisions actually levying the income are already in place. I make a couple of other comments. Senator Jack Evans quoted Odgers. Odgers said that it was not 'deemed by the Senate'. Frankly, it does not matter what Odgers says, or what the Senate deems. The final responsibility for determining matters like this rests with the High Court of Australia. I understand that some time ago, in 1959, a case which has some relevance to this question was put before the Court, but I believe that it is a matter which ought to be clarified. It does not matter what Odgers, or what Parliamentary Counsel or what the Senate as a whole says. This question ought to be determined in the Court and nowhere else. Without doubt, leaving aside legal escape clauses and rationalisations, the introduction of a Bill such as this into the Senate unequivocally breaches the spirit of the Constitution because it imposes a tax on some taxpayers which did not previously exist. It makes them liable to pay tax on receipts previously exempt from taxation which would now be included. That is not an argument against the Bill itself. I am dealing with the point of whether the Bill ought to have been introduced in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that Senator Evans's comment that if Senator Tate's point of order were upheld it would erode the whole basis for the imposition of retrospection taxation falls to the ground. I think that has missed the point because Senator Tate's comments have nothing to do with the justification or otherwise of whether tax should be imposed retrospectively, but with the question of whether a Bill, the practical effect of which is to impose tax on people, ought to originate in the Senate. Senator Tate passed no judgment at all in his point of order on whether it was correct either in law or morally that such legislation should be enacted by the Parliament. Indeed, on many occasions Senator Tate's view on that latter question has been made very clear in the Senate. That is the same view which the Australian Labor Party has. It is the same view that Labor has stated unequivocally in Opposition; that is, where schemes are devised which are blatantly contrived to avoid taxation the Parliament does have the moral right, and indeed the moral obligation, to pass laws to see that the people who devise and benefit from such schemes are not allowed to rob their fellow taxpayers, which is ultimately what their actions boil down to.

This much can be said in favour of Senator Jack Evans's Bill: At least from 7 December 1983-and I make the point for the record that that also has retrospective application-the tax liability with respect to the cherry picker schemes will be quite clear. It has been argued on previous occasions by a number of people in the Opposition that there is a possibility-they probably put it stronger than possibility-that existing law could be used to deal with people who manage and benefit from cherry picker schemes. It is not the view of the Government that the existing law could have been used effectively in that way.

Hence the Government decided to legislate. In a moment I will give the reasons why the Government decided to make that legislation applicable from July 1977. The virtue of Senator Jack Evans's Bill is that from 7 December 1983 it puts the matter beyond doubt. However, the Government is very strongly of the view that it is the Government's Bill which ought to be passed. But if the Government's Bill is referred to a committee, which I understand is likely to happen today, the Government will not oppose Senator Evans's Bill. I want to make one comment on his final point in his second reading speech. He stated:

The choice for Government members is clear. Will they continue to play politics in order to arouse public anger at what governments have allowed tax avoiders to do in the past, or will they support this Bill which will prevent further abuses of this type in the future? Are they serious about tax avoidance or are they using tax avoidance to play politics?

I think that is a completely unwarranted comment and I say so for this reason: The ingenuity of what is euphemistically called the tax avoidance industry has been quite remarkable over many years. It is not just a question of picking up people who have defrauded fellow taxpayers of at least $1m, as the Kelly brothers did. This was documented in the Kelly v. Raymor case. It is a question of deterring all future tax avoiders. It is the Government's belief, asserted unequivocally in opposition and in government, that once the threat of the imposition of retrospective taxation or amendment to the law to impose the tax which ought to have been paid when blatant schemes have been contrived to avoid tax is seen to be credible, the entire tax avoidance industry will collapse. It is for that reason that the Government's Bill, rather than Senator Jack Evans's Bill, ought to be supported. Mr Deputy President, I think that technically I may have the right to reply again in this debate because I am now addressing Senator Jack Evans's Bill rather than the Government's Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are correct but you will have to confine your remarks exclusively to Senator Evans's Bill if you wish to have a right of reply on the other Bill.

—It is a cognate debate and it is my intention now to speak on both the Bills rather than reply at the end of the cognate debate on behalf of the Government to the Government's Bill as I would otherwise have done. It seems to me, all things considered, that it would be better for me to enter the debate on both Bills at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who spoke at some length about the information which Mr Howard had previously tabled in the House of Representatives as a rationale, an excuse or a justification for the failure of the previous Government to take action against the cherry picker schemes. The substance of that as I understood it-I trust I have understood it correctly-is that at that stage at least it was the then Government's belief that the law as it applied to the Part IVA amendments, which were made, I think, in late 1981, was adequate to deal with the cherry picker schemes. If that remains the belief of the Opposition-it is not clear to me whether that is the belief of the Opposition-what it is saying is that there is no need for the Government's Bill and there is no need for Senator Evans's Bill either because the existing law can be effectively used against cherry picker scheme operators. I would welcome clarification from the Opposition as to whether that is its view.

Senator Macklin said quite erroneously that the Government had provided no justification for the backdating provision in the Government's Bill; that is, to make what is the same amendment as Senator Evans's amendment applicable from 1977 instead of 1983. That is quite false. The Government has provided justification for that. Firstly, there is a significant amount of revenue, estimated to be of the order of $15m and possibly quite higher and secondly, the principle, the principle I stress, of whether the people who perpetrated the notorious Kelly v. Raymor case fraud-some people quibble about whether the fraud was against fellow taxpayers or their employees-should be able to retain the $1m or so which they picked up as a result of their fraudulent activities. The Government says: 'No, they should not be allowed to retain that $1m effectively stolen from other taxpayers', or for those who prefer it from the employees of the company. The Government's view is that it was stolen from fellow taxpayers but even to those who believe it was stolen from the employees of the company the moral judgment ought to be the same.

The Kelly brothers should not be allowed to retain the $1m-plus which they fraudulently obtained from some source or other. The Government's view on the Kelly brothers case-there are probably others but the Kelly v. Raymor case is one case which is known because it came into court, for completely different reasons-is that people such as the Kelly brothers should not be able to retain the money that they obtained in that way. Those who will not support the Government's Bill clearly take the view that the Kelly brothers ought to be able to retain that money, as should other people who acted in circumstances similar to the way in which the Kelly brothers acted. Additionally, if the Senate passes the Government's Bill a very clear warning will have been given to all potential tax avoiders: People who blatantly contrive schemes to deprive the public of tax revenue will not get away with any blatant contrived scheme in the future.

Senator Macklin also claimed-I must say I found Senator Macklin's speech a little confusing; if I have not got it correctly it is due to misunderstanding and not to any intention to misrepresent him-that the Commissioner of Taxation, under the existing law, could review and reassess tax liability of both the funds and the companies which claimed deductions from corporate income over the entire period the funds were in operation. He claimed that the Commissioner had the power retrospectively to reassess-although 'retrospective' and 'reassessment ' are, I suppose, tautologous-the tax liability of those companies over the entire period that the schemes were in operation, both for company tax deduction and for exemption by the funds for income earned by investment within the funds. Legally, I think that that is at least arguable, but let us assume that that is legally correct and that it would be possible for the Commissioner to do this. One obvious objection is that it would be extraordinarily complicated and would occupy human and other resources within the Taxation Office which could and probably should be better applied to other activities. Secondly, and equally importantly, there is knowledge that at least in some cases the companies would have no assets to pay the liabilities which the Commissioner reassessed, and therefore the money would be irrecoverable unless the Commissioner were to attempt to recover the money from the beneficiaries of the defunct companies, which quite clearly the present law does not allow the Commissioner to do.

Senator Macklin also asserted that the cherry picker-type scheme had been uncovered by the previous Labor Government. I have no knowledge of it being correct and I do not think that there is anything on the public record or in private records which supports that. I suspect that Sentor Macklin did not mean to say that. As far as I am aware, the previous Labor Government detected no cherry picker schemes. Indeed, the first occasion upon which these schemes were detected by anyone was in about 1977. Senator Macklin also claimed that the Government's action in introducing this Bill was in conflict with the policies which we had stated prior to the electon. That is completely wrong. We stated prior to the election, and the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, stated again on , I think, 30 March last year, what the Government's attitude is towards blatant and contrived tax avoidance schemes, and that is that the beneficiaries of such schemes should be forced to disgorge the benefits that they had improperly gained.

I do not think that there is much point in going over all the arguments relevant to this scheme or to the principle of retrospectivity. They were extensively canvassed the last time this Bill was debated in the Senate. Before closing, however, I want to give notice of a procedural intention on the part of the Government. I understand that an agreement was reached between all the Whips this morning to have a cognate debate on these two Bills, and that at the end of that debate the second reading vote on the Government Bill would be taken. I understand that although no amendment has been circulated, an amendment will be moved to refer the Government Bill to a committee. If that amendment were carried, Senator Jack Evans's Bill would then come on for a second reading vote and the Government would support it. I am informed that that is the agreement which was reached. Intentionally or otherwise, the motion that Senator Chipp-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; we genuinely did not know of such agreement.
—All right; I will accept that. Perhaps there was a misunderstanding. But that is the Government Whip's advice to me. As a result of Senator Chipp's procedural motion moved earlier today-
—Which you knew about; we told you about that. We gave you notice that I was going to do that.
—The only notice that I received was a request for a cognate debate. The Government had no objection to that.
—No. We gave you notice that I was going to do that.

—I am not trying to apportion blame or whatever. Clearly, there was some confusion. As a result of Senator Chipp's procedural motion moved earlier today, the second reading vote on the Australian Democrats' Bill will be taken prior to that on the Government Bill. At an appropriate stage the Government Whip will move that the second reading vote on the Government Bill be taken first. Apart from a principle, which the Senate is not necessarily obliged to accept-that where there are two very similar measures, the Government measure ought to be the one that is voted first-logically it follows that the Government Bill should be put to the vote first, because if the Government Bill should be carried, Senator Jack Evans's Bill clearly becomes redundant. So the logical sequence for taking the vote is that the Government Bill comes first, the Democrats' Bill comes second, if it is still relevant after the vote on the Government Bill has been taken. At the appropriate stage, which will probably be at the end of the second reading debate, the Government Whip will be moving accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats applaud the statement by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) that the Government will not oppose this Australian Democrats' private member's Bill originating from my colleague Senator Jack Evans. We are glad also of the support indicated by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle from the Opposition. So it would seem that this Bill will pass the Senate unanimously. That is as it should be, because we are dealing with the matter which has been called cherry picking, a tax fraud of an extraordinarily cynical and unpleasant nature in which firms used the concessions for tax deductibility for their payments allegedly for superannuation for their employees but in fact to acquire those moneys for themselves and thereby avoid paying tax. These firms used various devices, including sacking or forced retirement, to see that all the benefits of that superannuation came to the owners of the business. That was the picking of the cherries.

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem that all honourable senators agree with the general principle that this practice ought to be stopped. The enormous importance of this Bill which we have brought forward is that it has cleared the air, it has brought in a necessary holding operation, and that this practice will cease from the date on which it was first made public, 7 December last year. I think that there is general agreement that that date is fair and does not involve any principle of retrospectivity. Senator Jack Evans and I both regard the principle of tax equity as more important than that of retrospectivity. Our further votes in this matter will continue to be informed by that belief.

As to the question of the reference to a committee, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has raised a point that has value. A short reference will not do any harm to the Government Bill. It will clear up points which the Opposition and the Australian Democrats hold as being of concern. The reference will be resolved this month. As Senator Macklin said, there is general agreement that there will be no extension to that reference, so I do not think that any claim can be made that this is a delaying or a blocking tactic. It becomes of less importance especially with the Jack Evans Bill passed, because that will then hold and control the present situation.

This Bill is designed to include in assessable income the value of certain benefits derived from or in connection with certain section 23F superannuation funds. It will insert a new section 26A, which will operate where benefits are received or obtained in circumstances where the taxpayer had no rights under the fund rules to receive the benefits, or where the benefits paid were excessive for the purposes of paragraph 23F(2)(h). In other words, it will prevent further abuses of the kind outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech when introducing the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984.

We deplore the fact that 23F funds have been used for tax avoidance. This story is not over. The Government's Bill is by no means rendered redundant, nor does it end, with the passage of the Democrats' private member's Bill. The Democrats have been consistent in their view of this matter. We have been consistent in our fight against tax evaders and in our support of legislation against tax evaders. I deeply resent the imputations made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the Democrats have been the friends of tax cheats, as he said in a speech in Adelaide which was broadcast-a recording of the Prime Minister's own words-on the AM program on 19 April 1984. My fellow Democrats, Senators Chipp, Haines and Macklin have been consistent in their stand on principle against any form of retrospective legislation. I understand fully their point of view. I again naturally understand the point of view put forward by Senator Jack Evans and me. We are not unaware of the dangers of retrospectivity. We are also aware of the great dangers to this community of a failure of tax equity, and on balance and consistently we have regarded that point of tax equity as being the more important one. We will continue to do that. On that basis, I would like to refer briefly to the Prime Minister's comments on the AM program. I quote from a transcript of that program. He said:

I have a fairly firm conviction the Australian people are not going to look with a great deal of satisfaction upon the fact that they, the ordinary law- abiding citizens and taxpayers of this country, have been milked, as I say, of over $500m by these friends of the tax avoiders-the Liberals, the Nationals and the Democrats.
I stress particularly those words 'the Democrats' which are repeated four times in this statement from the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister said:

. . . I'll be saying around Australia in the weeks and months ahead, and the Liberals and the National Party and the Democrats will not be able to move away from this. They will be labelled as the people who have cost Australians half a billion dollars by their refusal on three occasions to pass through the Senate the legislation which this government put through the House of Represenatives.
Finally, the Prime Minister said:
And as I say I tell the Liberals and the Nationals and Democrats now, I give them notice, that they will be hounded and reminded of that fact for every week between now and the elections.

On Friday last Hillman and Woolf, solicitors for Senator Jack Evans and me, submitted letters of demand to the Prime Minister requiring him to withdraw those statements, to apologise and to retract generally. In the words of our solicitor's letter:

Our clients require an apology and retraction in respect of your defamatory comments in terms drafted by us and enclosed. This apology and retraction is to be broadcasted nationally on the 'AM' programme of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and is to be published in a prominent position in at least one daily morning newspaper published and circulated in each of the Australian capital Cities.
The first letter from Hillman and Woolf to the Prime Minister says:
Our instructions are to commence proceedings against you claiming damages.
In a further letter of the same day, we say to the Prime Minister:

If you provide the apology and retraction and agree to its publication as required in our open letter, we will recommend to our clients that they not take any further proceedings in respect of the defamatory publication.

We have had no response this morning from the Prime Minister or from his solicitors, and Senator Jack Evans and I will now consider our further position in that matter. I think I can say at this stage, as no writ has yet been entered on the Prime Minister by us, that it is scandalous that the Prime Minister should make this kind of statement. He is absolutely aware that Senator Jack Evans and I have consistently voted for his legislation, yet in Adelaide he allows himself to be quoted in the Press as trying to put all the Democrats in the same basket. This is not to canvass my colleagues' attitude-I have made that clear already-but the Prime Minister has deliberately and with aforethought said that he proposes not only to punish Senator Jack Evans and me for something we have not done but also to hound us week by week between now and the election. His only intention in that, I take it, is to try to obtain defeat of Australian Democrats senators in the election which is to come. I think it is obvious enough to you, Mr Deputy President, and to other honourable senators that, if he were to succeed in that intent on this basis, he might well be personally disadvantaged. I make it quite plain here that we will take the same kind of action against any other member of this place, any other person or any media who might want to take the same line.
Motion (by Senator Robertson) put:
That the debate be now adjourned.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Given that the Senate has now made the decision that Senator Evans's Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill will be voted on before the Government's Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) the Government, as I said before, will not oppose Senator Evans's Bill. However, that raises the question of what then happens to Senator Evans's Bill vis-a-vis the House of Representatives. Apart from the time constraints and the pressure of government business in the House of Representatives, the Government may need to examine the legal ramifications, if any, pertaining to a possible reintroduction of the Government Bill to amend an Act which by then will already have been amended. This of course will be the situation if Senator Evans's Bill is passed by the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate long. I believe that it is appropriate that I speak because accusations that the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill is a friend of tax cheats are being levelled in public. Once again I record my views on tax cheats and retrospectivity. No honest person-I do not put it any higher than that-could accuse me, with over 24 years of parliamentary experience, or my colleagues, Senator Macklin and Senator Haines-or for that matter any member of the Liberal Party-of being friends of tax cheats. That is a monstrous accusation. Such an accusation should be made only in the face of evidence. As I said before, I put it no higher than that. No honest person, or person purporting to be the most honest man in Australia, should ever make such an accusation, even if it is made in the heat of politics.

SPEECH.PARA: After having said that, the Australian Democrats and I commend the Government for trying to close the loophole of the cherry picker scheme. The fact that an Australian Democrat senator, Senator Jack Evans, has introduced a Bill that will do that and that the Liberal Party is supporting the Bill, indicates their concurrence that this scheme should be stopped. The scheme is iniquitous and evil. It is a scheme which Senator Walsh quite properly described as ripping money off one's mates, one's fellow taxpayers, for one's personal gain. What is entailed is that a business, normally a smallish business, would deduct salary payments for payment into an employee's superannuation fund, get a tax deduction for those amounts and then when the employee became entitled to payment from the scheme-sometimes employees do not even know that such a scheme had been raised in their name-that employee would be retired early, sacked or retrenched by the owner of the business or the trustees of the fund who put the money tax free into their own pockets. That is a damnable, rotten and despicable scheme which should be stopped. The passing of this legislation will do that.

As with the bottom of the harbour legislation the Democrats and the Liberals are totally united in their opposition to people who cheat the system. That is one principle. My colleagues Senator Mason and Senator Evans agree also with this. However, they go further. As was described by the previous Prime Minister there are two conflicting principles. One such principle involves chasing and punishing tax cheats-an activity with which I believe all of us concur. However, another principle involves retrospectivity in legislation. My colleagues Senator Jack Evans and Senator Colin Mason have succinctly described their reasons for believing that chasing tax cheats is more important in principle to them-a principle which they passionately and genuinely hold-than the principle of retrospectivity. All members of the Labor Party honestly believe that also. I do not think that any member of the Labor Party would not believe that retrospectivity is evil. There is a question of judgment here as to which is the greater evil-abrogating a principle which I believe is dear to all people who hold to the rule of law or chasing after those despicable creatures who cheat their mates at tax.

I hold the view that once retrospective legislation is regarded as the norm, once a Parliament allows it on one occasion, there is an enormous danger that governments or politicians will follow it in other directions or will similarly legislate in other areas. I say, as do my colleagues Senator Macklin and Senator Haines, that once we have a society in which penal retrospective legislation becomes normal in our law making then we no longer live in a truly democratic society. It is as serious as that. I believe that governments and politicians have been to blame for the situation where tax cheats have been able to cheat the system for so long. I understand that politicians-I lay no blame on the Australian Taxation Office-knew about bottom of the harbour schemes as early as 1975-76. Politicians were asked by the Taxation Office, quite properly, to do something about it. Successive Labor and Liberal governments did nothing for five or six years. There was no fault on the Taxation Office but there was certainly fault on the politicians. Now the Parliament is being asked: 'We did not do anything about this for four or five years, will you fix it up by back dating five or six years or even longer?'. As far as I am concerned, on a matter of principle I will not accept that.

As with other senators I speak a great deal to schools, universities and other such groups. It is interesting that one of the questions I am asked is about retrospective taxation. Lately I have retorted by asking the class-only this week I spoke to two groups of 50 students all doing their Higher School Certificate or fifth form-'Be honest with me and put your hands up if you would know how to describe to your friends the meaning of retrospective legislation. How many of you would be confident of getting five out of 10 for your explanation?'. Inevitably only two or three kids put their hands up.

There is massive ignorance out there of the meaning of retrospectivity and the evil that that represents. I will give two examples. I instance a splendid cartoon showing Mr Malcolm Fraser as the parking inspector writing out a ticket for a car parked illegally. Beside him was standing Mr Howard. The next cartoon showed Mr Fraser walking to the next car with Mr Howard with a portable 'no parking' sign over his shoulder and about to plonk it down at the next car which was then illegally parked. That is a facetious example. When that is translated in terms of a person's livelihood it can become devastating. Let me give an example. All over the nation there are small businesses-chemist shops, delicatessens, milk bars, newsagencies, manufacturing businesses-in which spouses join with each other as partners in the business. It is normally a respectable, honourable, legal arrangment. Because it is a partnership, the profits are halved or split in certain proportions and the result is that the total amount of tax payable out of the profits is diminished to the extent that the income is split. As I say, it is legal, honourable and within the framework of the law.

Let us assume that a future government, in regard to spouses-and I wish, Mr President, that we could change the plural of spouse to spice; it makes so much sense, but such innovations take time-decided to make those sorts of partnership illegal and to deem all of the income to be in the hands, say, of the husband. We might say that that was unfair, a bit rough, but if the political party of the day campaigned on that measure, won office and brought it in, we would say ' Fair enough, it had a mandate', whatever that means. But what if it backdated that law 10 years? The Taxation Office would then be obliged to reopen every assessment it had made over that period, issue an assessment against every male person who had been engaged in a partnership with his wife and tax him double the original amount with penal tax. That person in many cases would now be retired, would have some sort of prospect of looking forward to old age, and would be totally devastated. Every cent he owned would go to pay the taxes that had been retrospectively applied. That is what retrospectivity means.

I give one more example. It is graphic, perhaps, but because of the ignorance or lack of knowledge in the community as to what retrospective laws mean, I believe it is essential for those of us who believe in the rule of law to keep thumping this lesson home. Otherwise the untruthful statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that because the Liberals and some Australian Democrats vote against retrospectivity therefore we are friends of tax cheats, will stick. If he is hounding us and thumping that home week after week between now and the election, I believe those of us who believe in the rule of law and who are against retrospectivity, similarly should repeat what are the evils of retrospectivity. The example I give is graphic but I believe it can be well understood. Today, at this time, somewhere in Australia, in every capital city, a termination of a pregnancy is taking place. It will be legal and totally within the law. It will be performed by a fully qualified medical practitioner in a public hospital. A qualified nurse will be in attendance and the operation will be known to the medical superintendent of the hospital, who will approve because it will be conducted within the framework of the law. It is a moral question, as is the question of tax evasion. Many senators in this chamber have very serious views about abortion, which I respect.

Let us assume that a political party gained office in this country on 1 December, that had as part of its platform that all abortions or terminations of pregnancies under any circumstances should be illegal, should be a crime and should be punishable by a mandatory gaol sentence. I could say: 'Fair enough, people have those strong views about abortion and if a political party puts that forward, it is quite entitled to do so'. If that political party were elected it would be absolutely entitled to bring in such a law. In that hypothetical situation that political party would bring in a law to make the performing of termination of pregnancies a criminal offence. But what if that political party dated it back 10 years? It would mean that the doctor who is at present performing the operation, the woman upon whom it is being performed, the nurse who is in attendance and the medical superintendent of the hospital would all be guilty of a criminal offence and all would go to gaol, even though now, when it is being performed, it is perfectly legal and five years ago when it was performed somewhere else it was perfectly legal. It would be deemed to be a crime because a government is elected and retrospectively dates its legislation.

Students of history will remember that Adolph Hilter used that measure with devastating effect in Germany. In 1938 he brought in a law that any meeting of Jews had to have the permission of the prefect of police of the district, and he dated it back to 1933. If any Jews met anywhere without a permit from the prefect of police they were guilty of a criminal offence. Every Jew who had been to a synagogue between 1933 and 1938 was immediately deemed to have committed a criminal offence and was put into a concentration camp. That is what retrospective legislation empowers politicians to do. While I am a member of this Parliament I will fight retrospectivity in every cause. I am desperately disappointed that those of us who stand up for this great moral principle of the rule of law under which we live and which we take for granted can be blackguarded as we are by the Prime Minister today. If he wanted to say to the people of Australia 'There are two conflicting principles here; we choose to abrograte one of them to satisfy another honourable principle, namely, to catch tax cheats' that would be one thing. But to call people who opposes his view, on the very respectable ground that the rule of law in a democracy must prevail, tax cheats is despicable and, as far as I know, unlike the man I knew to be Bob Hawke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Senate wishes to conclude this debate by midday, so perforce I will be brief. I would not have entered the debate apart from the fact that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) made some quite extravagant claims in his closing remarks . Again, as so often occurs in debates on taxation matters, extravagant language overruns the facts. Senator Walsh continually used words such as 'fraud', ' fraudulent' and 'stolen'. If either the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1984 or the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 were to go before the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I would want to ask the Australian Taxation Office: Is it a fact that if a fraud has been committed on the Commissioner of Taxation through a false return, the Commissioner has powers under his own Act, the Crimes Act or State criminal law to prosecute the people involved and to have them either fined or gaoled if convicted?

SPEECH.PARA: I would have further thought that where there is not full disclosure in one's income tax return-and full disclosure by the courts has been very narrowly defined; it is almost impossible to make full disclosure under some decisions- the Commissioner has the right to re-open the assessment as far back as one's birth, as far back as he likes to go; whereas, as I understand the tax law, if there is full disclosure within that very narrow definition there is a time limit on how far he can go back to reopen the assessment. All these cherry picking schemes are alleged to have been based on some criminal or quasi- criminal offence. One would have thought that the Commissioner of Taxation, with his normal powers would have the right to re-open those assessments and to re- assess either the corporation or certainly the persons who claim the lifting of their tax liability because of their contribution to these funds. I would have thought the Commissioner could have gone and re-assessed either the corporation, the taxpayer or the individual taxpayer over that period. It really is no answer to me that he now may well be dealing with men of straw because men of straw, in re-opening an assessment, would basically still be men of straw; one would not recover from them on retrospective legislation.

The worrying things about the whole business of retrospective legislation are the matters which were averted to by Mr Gyles and Mr Redlich last year when those two special prosecutors reported to Parliament. The Age newspaper of Tuesday 15 November last year had rather a largish headline entitled: 'Tax man ignored advice, says QC'. I have always been struck by what Mr Gyles said as part of his report when he was talking about the differing opinions between the then Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers, and a report prepared by Mr Murray Gleeson, QC, a Sydney barrister. He stated:
All I am saying is that with two such eminent people expressing such divergent views the place to resolve them is in the High Court, not the back room.

That criticism has never been answered by the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) nor by the present Commissioner of Taxation or the Taxation Office. Whilst I agree absolutely and totally in adopting the arguments of Senator Chipp as to the evils of retrospectivity as a principle, I am not satisfied in all the legislation that has been coming before us-be it the Fraser Government's legislation or the Hawke Government's legislation-that the administration of the tax laws, as they stand, have been properly used against the alleged tax cheats of this country. If one goes back to what became known as the Brinsden opinion of the early 1970s-the whole sorry story which came out of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-one will see there has obviously been an administrative ineptness between the Attorney-General's Department and the Taxation Office. It is no answer to send off the former Crown Solicitor who was later Secretary to that Department and put him on the Federal Court of Australia as a judge and say: ' That is the end of that book'. I am still not satisfied that a proper investigation and re-organisation of those departments has done anything to clean up this administrative mess of at least 10 years' standing.

I repeat that I regret that if Senator Jack Evans's Bill, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill, is accepted and the Government does not go on with its Bill, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2), and it is defeated, we will not have the opportunity on the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations really to quiz to some extent the officials of the Taxation Office. I believe it is screamingly necessary in this country to have an investigation into the administration of the Income Tax Assessment Act. We talk about having all sorts of investigations, royal commissions and everything else into the tax system and into the various types of taxes. We have had reports from the Asprey Taxation Review Committee and all sorts of fancy things about how one shifts tax burdens or shuffles the pack and all the rest of it. Long ago I concluded that what is needed is an absolute investigation into the administration of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Commissioner ought to be called to account as to why he has not used the enormous, and in many cases draconian powers, which he has under the present legislation. Merely to hide behind the device that the Attorney-General's Department thought we might not win I think is insufficient. I believe that public officers have a public duty to test their powers in the courts. In my view, public officers fail in their duty if they refuse to test their powers in court and merely rely on legal opinion.

I think it is because of the fear which crept into the Taxation Office about what might happen to it in the High Court of Australia over section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act that in the last 20 years we have seen this whole industry get out of hand. I blame successive Commissioners of Taxation for not continually going back to the High Court and arguing what section 260 used to mean in law and means to any person of reasonable intelligence who picks up the ordinary and sensible meaning of those words. I always thought it was an act of legal cowardice for Taxation Office officials to sit down and accept some of the rulings of the High Court on that matter. I think it is to their eternal disgrace that they were not nagging the Parliament day after day to strengthen section 260. It was finally brought up to date with Part VIA under John Howard.

For those and other reasons I will never go along with retrospective taxation. I am not satisfied that either in this case or any of the other cases where taxpayers have been abused that the Taxation Office has properly used its powers . I therefore ask that unless Senator Walsh is going to tell us that either the Taxation Office, the Federal Police or State Police or somebody is going to prosecute these fraudulent people, all these stealers of taxpayers' money, for what he is firstly saying are criminal offences, he has no right to walk around talking about stolen money or fraudulent practices. If there are fraudulent practices, Senator, those who indulge in them must be prosecuted for fraud. It was all right for an Opposition front bencher in the old days to make such statements, but the honourable senator is now a Minister of the Crown. For a Minister of the Crown to talk about people committing fraud without following through with prosecution, all I can say is that the Minister of the Crown is most probably derelict in his duty. For those reasons, if none other, I urge upon Senator Walsh either to carry out his duty and have the frauds prosecuted, or stop using such words.

—We are running short of time. I simply want to make it quite clear that the purpose of my Bill was to remove the uncertainty that exists now. Uncertainty exists as to whether the Government's legislation will get through. I want to take away that uncertainty and let people in the electorate know exactly what the position is, effective from 7 December when the Government first introduced its section 23F legislation. We want to let the people know that there will be no more loopholes; there will be no more ability for people to use schemes to avoid their tax obligations. SPEECH.PARA: I wish briefly to reiterate my record against tax evaders. The Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) has thrown a cloud across my reputation in Western Australia. I have supported every Bill to retrieve taxes that were avoided or evaded by people in Australia under the three bottom of the harbour schemes Bills, under the first cherry pickers superannuation fund Bill and now, through the introduction of my own Bill, to fight tax evaders in this country. I will further support the Government's new Bill provided there is justification for its retrospective elements as proven by that Senate Committee. I mention also that I introduced this private member's Bill to give the right of appeal to genuinely innocent shareholders of companies whose directors sent their companies to the bottom of the harbour. That would have applied to both the Fraser legislation and the Government's proposed legislation on bottom of the harbour operators. Some genuinely innocent people were caught up in that net who deserve to be let off and who should not be hit as ferociously as they are being hit by the Commissioner of Taxation at this moment.

Senator Mason and I have been consistent in our support of attacks on tax evaders. We believe that tax evaders and avoiders are a blight on our community. We believe that the day has come when tax avoidance must cease to be a notorious Australian business practice. I say that with a full appreciation of the honest and sincere views of some Democrats and other honourable senators and, incidentally, I might mention, about half of the population of Australia that retrospective tax laws are reprehensive and are a matter of principle. Nevertheless, the principle of tax equity is paramount. I am not canvassing an opinion on the constitutional point that was raised this morning but, interestingly, if that constitutional point is valid, is upheld and is used by the Government, what we are talking about is the machinery to hit tax avoiders, not the imposition of a new tax. I think that needs to be very clearly understood by everybody, both in this Senate and in the electorate. I ask honourable senators to support this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Yesterday at a joint Press conference with the Premier of South Australia, John Bannon, I indicated that we had agreed I would ask the British Government for its agreement to release the full text of what is known as the Pearce report. That report produced by the British Government in January 1968, deals with the question of residual radioactive contamination at Maralinga in South Australia. An edited version of that report was published in May 1979 and tabled in the House of Representatives by the then Minister for National Development on 7 June 1979. In its original form the Pearce report was a classified document as it contains information on the nature of some of the tests and materials used. In addition the report specifically records the location of various waste burials and their contents. The edited version deletes certain references to aspects of the tests and to the burial sites.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of claims that have been made by the late Mr Burke and others that there are unmarked and unknown burial sites, I felt it would be in the public interest to have the full report released. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that the British Government has responded positively and promptly to this request. I seek leave to table a copy of the unedited version of the report.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Unfortunately very few copies of the original document are in Australia. Arrangements are being made to have the report reprinted as quickly as possible but in the meantime I have arranged for a few copies to be placed in the Parliamentary Library. I note for the record that the copy which is being tabled say on its cover sheet: 'This is the only copy held by DNDE'. That, of course, is no longer relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: I also sought an assurance from the British Government that it had no knowledge of any waste burial sites arising from the tests other than those set out in the Pearce report. I table a letter dated 4 May from the British High Commission in Canberra advising that to the best of the British Government's knowledge and belief there are no burial sites in existence resulting from the Maralinga tests other than those described in the full Pearce report.

Yesterday in response to a question from Senator Cook, in confirming that a small quantity of plutonium had been returned to the United Kingdom in 1979, I said that as part of an agreement between the United Kingdom and Australian governments, Australia had agreed to accept entirely the responsibility for the rest of the contaminated waste material at Maralinga and that the United Kingdom had no further responsibility to have any other contaminated material repatriated to the United Kingdom. Again with the concurrence of the British Government, I have arranged for the exchange of documents relating to this matter to be made public and table a copy of a note dated 29 November 1978 to the British Government and its response of 4 January 1979, as well as the bout de papier referred to in the High Commissioner's letter.

While there is understandable concern on the part of the public about the various claims and allegations regarding Maralinga in the last few days this has not been helped by overreaction and misreporting by some sections of the media and by continuing suggestions of secrecy on the part of the Australian and British governments. Typical of this is a claim in the Canberra Times today stating that details were revealed yesterday of another previously unpublicised Federal Government report on the 1979 program to remove a plutonium mass from Maralinga. The plain fact is that the report, entitled, 'Management of Former United Kingdom Atomic Test Sites in Australia-Report of 1979 Work Program', was presented in both Houses of the Parliament on 7 June 1979, and a Press release was also issued.

Finally, let me assure the Senate and the Australian people that this Government has no interest or intention of keeping facts relating to the nuclear tests in Australia secret. We are dealing with events that date back some thirty years. There are voluminous records scattered throughout various Commonwealth departments and archives in Australia and the same situation exists in the United Kingdom. My Department is continuing efforts to bring together all relevant documents and information, and I am advised that a similar process is proceeding in the United Kingdom. As I have already announced, later this year the Government will receive a report covering the history of the Maralinga and Emu test series and that will be published. In the meantime, I invite any person who has information believed to be of relevance to come forward and to contact me or my Department. I present the following paper:
Maralinga Weapons Tests-Ministerial Statement, 4 May 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

As I have had a copy of the statement for a matter of only 10 or 15 minutes and it was the view of the Opposition that it was in the public interest that the statement should be made before the Senate rises today, I do not wish to say very much. I also wish to make it clear, Mr Deputy President, that it is the wish of the Opposition to deal with the Government's tax legislation and to move a motion which would refer that legislation to a committee. We would like to see that motion dealt with forthwith so that the Committee to which the legislation is referred can examine the legislation quickly and report back to the Senate quickly, and thereby not unduly delay the Government's legislative program.

The only comments on the statement which I wish to make at this stage are to pick up the point which was made by the Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) with respect to continuing suggestions of secrecy and his words at the end of his statement when he issued the invitation to any person who has information believed to be of relevance to come forward and to contact him or his Department. I merely say that that invitation is the latest in a series of invitations which have been issued by Senator Walsh's predecessor, Senator Sir John Carrick. I stress that it has always been the view of the Opposition, as it was the view of the previous Government, that this sort of matter should be dealt with openly and thoroughly and that any concern should be raised and dealt with and investigated in an appropriate manner.

I draw the Senate's attention to some of the earlier evidence of that approach. Senator Walsh has already referred to the fact that one secret report was actually tabled in this place. I remind the Senate of the report of the Australian Ionising and Radiation Advisory Council dated January 1983 and entitled 'British Nuclear Tests in Australia-A Review of Operational Safety Measures and of Possible After-effects'. That report dealt, inter alia, with issues which have been raised recently. I note that in the Summary at paragraph 1.18 it is stated:

The precautions taken to ensure that Aboriginals living in the area were not endangered by the nuclear tests were carefully planned and executed and AIRAC has found no evidence that any Aboriginals were injured by the nuclear tests.

I do not quote that as saying that is the end of the matter. If new evidence, new material, is available by all means it should be brought forward and examined. The other report I want to remind the Senate of is the report of the Commonwealth Department of Health entitled 'Health of Atomic Test Personnel'. That contains a great deal of information about the work which was done under Senator Sir John Carrick to ensure that all personnel who had participated in the test programs were as far as possible followed up, that their health situation was examined and a careful examination was made of whether there was any evidence of damage to the health of those personnel. Time does not permit me to go into any detail, but I think it is important if we are to have these matters dealt with sensibly that it be acknowledged that there has been a wish on the part of successive governments to deal with these matters openly. The view taken is that there is nothing to hide and certainly that nothing should be hidden. I seek leave to continue my remarks later, Mr Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me I would like to refer very briefly to a meeting which recently took place in Tokyo , the regional inter-governmental preparatory meeting for the world conference to review and appraise the achievements of the United Nations Decade for Women- Equality, Development and Peace. On that occasion I had the honour to be included in the Australian delegation to the meeting in Tokyo which was established in order for this region of the United Nations to prepare a report which will go to the end of the decade conference to be held in Nairobi in July next year. On that occasion 32 nations of the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific region were represented in Tokyo. They represented the vast majority of nations, with the exception of some of the smaller Pacific nations which were unable to send representatives. It seems to me that one of Australia' s roles in the region should be to make certain that those small Pacific nations with very poor resources are given every opportunity to be represented at such forums.

SPEECH.PARA: During the course of the conference we were able to put together a report and a set of recommendations which, as I said earlier, are designed to go with the reports of the three other regional conferences to the Committee which will prepare the end of the decade conference in Nairobi in July next year. Showing some sensitivity on this occasion, Australia, one of the very fortunate countries in the region, was able, I think, to provide, as it does at other conferences of that nature, a certain intermediary role. It was a matter of some gratification for me to find that as an Australian I was able not only to fulfil the position of rapporteur for the conference but also to be involved in discussions with a wide range of countries and delegations from the region.

One of the other very highly satisfactory outcomes of the conference was that subsequently an Australian woman of great calibre, Justice Elizabeth Evatt, was elected at the subsequent ESCAP meeting to be one of the members of the expert committee which deals with the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women. I found it extremely gratifying to have represented Australia at the conference and, as I say, to have been able to fulfil the role of a conciliator within the conference, obviously representing a country to which all other delegations were able to come and discuss issues. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12 noon, in accordance with Sessional Orders, I now call on Questions without Notice.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs agree with the Minister for Resources and Energy that the terms in which Mr Hugh Morgan expressed his concern about the implications of Aboriginal land rights for the mining industry, to quote the Minister, 'do not necessarily invalidate the case itself'. Does she share the Minister's concern that, since 1981, 165 exploration licences have been offered to 42 companies on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory and none have successfully negotiated agreements?

—In my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and, I am sure, representing the Government generally, I share Senator Walsh's condemnation of the terms in which Mr Morgan chose to make a public statement about the problems for the mining industry in the implementation of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. I have no knowledge of the precise number of exploration licences which have been applied for, nor how many have been granted or how many are still under consideration. I am aware that sections of the mining industry are concerned about delays. Naturally, our Government will take those concerns separately. However-I am trying to remember the end of Senator Kilgariff's question-I certainly cannot give detailed comment on the number of licences. It is the intention of our Government, in the land rights area, as in every other area, to resolve dilemmas or possible problems by consultation with all parties concerned and certainly not to go down the track that Mr Morgan has apparently gone down of trying to create some racist backlash against Aboriginal land owners in the Northern Territory by describing them in such derogatory terms. I am perfectly confident that my colleague Senator Walsh, the Minister for Energy and Resources, and my colleague Mr Clyde Holding, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, will be able-through discussion, and consultation with miners and Aboriginal land owners in the Northern Territory-to overcome any legitimate difficulties that may exist with regard to the development of mining in that Territory.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer to the first part of the question. However, I think she said that she had missed some of the figures in the second part. I shall repeat it. The second part of my question is: Does she share the Minister's concern that, since 1981, 165 exploration licences have been offered to 42 companies on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory and none has successfully negotiated agreements?

—If that matter is a matter for concern by Senator Walsh, then he is the appropriate Minister to express that concern. I would need to know a lot more about why so many licences were applied for, the extent of current mining projects on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory and a great deal of other background material before I could place in context the figure of 165 unapproved applications for exploration licences. The question is complex. Yesterday my colleague Senator Walsh expressed some sympathy with the miners' view, and I am sure that he is exploring that sensitively. I conclude my answer to Senator Kilgariff's supplementary question by saying this: Our Government is firmly committed to Aboriginal land rights. We welcome the fact that a substantial part of the Northern Territory is now owned by traditional Aboriginal owners.
—Welcome it?

—Welcome it. I said we welcomed that fact. As the honourable senator will recall, the Whitlam Government introduced land rights legislation into the Northern Territory but did not have the chance to implement it. We welcome the fact that the Fraser Government proceeded with that legislation, even though with some amendments, and that in a bipartisan manner land rights for traditional Aboriginal owners in the Northern Territory have been established. I think there is bipartisan support for that development throughout this chamber and in the community. If there are difficulties with regard to delays in the consideration of applications for exploration, those matters will be addressed by my colleagues Senator Walsh and Mr Holding. I conclude by saying that any problems which have arisen or which appear to have arisen ought, in the view of our Government, to be resolved by consultation with all parties concerned; that is, the Aboriginal owners themselves and the miners.

—I preface my questions, which I direct to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, by saying that I am receiving an increasing number of complaints from constituents about inordinate delays in the resolution of their repatriation pension applications. I ask: Is the Minister also receiving an increasing number of complaints? Is he aware of the concern within the ex- service community about this matter and what does he propose to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be true to say that my predecessor, Senator Messner, would have been aware, as I have become aware in the 14 months I have been Minister for Veterans' Affairs, of the quite unacceptable delays occurring in the repatriation benefits determining system. That, of course, is what prompted the establishment of the Repatriation Review Tribunal to examine ways and means by which these delays could be overcome. As far as the current position is concerned, as at 29 March 1984 the mean times taken to process claims and appeals were worse than they were when Senator Messner was Minister. It now takes 288 days to deal with claims. Applications for increased pensions take 248 days and appeals to go through the processes have now got to the unacceptable state of taking 777 days to be dealt with. ANSWER.PARA: I have exercised my rights as a Minister to take whatever administrative steps are available to the Government. There have been major reforms in the investigative processes. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Teague rose to ask a question about Mr Campbell's views I thought he was going to ask me about emu farms because, according to what Mr Campbell said on the AM program this morning, considerable interest has been expressed by his Aborginal constituency in emu farms.

—Senator Teague asked about statements he claims have been made by Mr Campbell about the needs of his Aboriginal constituents. During the period I was shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I visited his electorate frequently, precisely to have discussions with Aboriginal communities about their demands and aspirations. I certainly agree with Mr Campbell, if Senator Teague is quoting him properly, that they have a great concern for educational opportunities, housing and, indeed, for basic things such as running water, which some communities do not have. They have enormous transport problems; they need better health services, more decentralised health services and so on. I would certainly endorse Mr Campbell's view that there are many urgent needs in the area of social policy in his entire electorate, which of course extends beyond the Kimberleys, and that his Aboriginal constituents are very much aware of those things and are very vigorous in pointing out their needs to Mr Campbell and to any other politicians who visit those areas. ANSWER.PARA: Since the question was directed to me as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I conclude by saying that our policy is that land rights for Aboriginal owners ought to be recognised. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Housing been drawn to a report in the Australian Financial Review today in which the Housing Industry Association is said to have attributed 10,000 more homes being built than would otherwise have been the case to the Hawke Government's first home ownership scheme?
