—I am sure that all honourable senators are aware, even if they did not read the Australian Financial Review this morning, of the enormous success of our first home owners scheme. I am very pleased that that success has been endorsed by an article in the Australian Financial Review, Australia's premier financial journal.
—Have you shares in it?

—The news that 10,000 additional homes are available to Australians as a result of this scheme is something that everybody, even Senator Archer, must surely welcome. I expect too that there will be continued development in the home building industry as a result of our scheme because information provided to me by the Department of Housing and Construction is to the effect that 69,000 applications for assistance have been received in the period from 1 October to 27 April. So I agree with Senator Sibraa that the scheme has been outstandingly successful first of all in its primary objective-to assist Australians to get homes, Australians who would not otherwise have been able to get them. Of course there are many related benefits and advantages in such a rapid development in the home building industry. These have to do with job creation in the building and construction industry and increases in demand in retail areas connected with furnishing and furbishing of homes, and so on. Even the most jaundiced critic of the Government must agree, as the Australian Financial Review has pointed out this morning, that the scheme has been overwhelmingly successful.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is it correct that key computer staff and consultants engaged by the Government for a 12-month period to prepare the assets test computer programs have been given notice? If it is correct, does that mean that the Government has decided to abandon the assets and income test legislation, despite the fact that the panel chaired by Professor Fred Gruen has not yet reported its findings? If the Government has decided not to proceed with the assets test in any form, will the Minister confirm this to remove the uncertainty and worry now experienced by pensioners? If it is not correct that the staff concerned have been given notice or been warned to look for other jobs because the assets and income test legislation is likely to be abandoned, is it true that they have been given these instructions because the computer system purchased by the Government is unable to cope with the complexity of the proposed assets testing requirements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information at present on whether the Department has any non-departmental people working on the assets test. I shall seek to provide information for Senator Haines before the end of Question Time. As to the statement on whether or not the assets test will be forthcoming, she will be aware that the proposed assets test is being reviewed by a panel of community representatives. The Government will be awaiting the panel's report before it makes any decisions in this area. There has been no change from that position.

ANSWER.PARA: From my experience of representing Senator Grimes before the Estimates Committee on social security matters, where the matter of the employment or the deployment of staff originally engaged to work on the test was raised and pursued at great length by members of that Committee, it would appear to me-I will confirm this later-that any staff that had been engaged for that purpose either have been continued to be employed on the review or are being redeployed in other areas of the Department or, in some cases, in other Commonwealth departments. I hope to have more precise information about the employees to whom Senator Haines's question referred by the end of Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has spending on nursing care for veterans increased dramatically in real terms over the past decade or so? What are the implications of this fact for his portfolio, especially having regard to the Government's commitment relating to care of the aged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a dramatic increase in spending by my Department on nursing care for veterans over the past decade or so. The Commonwealth accepts the full costs of nursing home accommodation required by veterans for service-related disabilities. In current prices, the Department spent $4m, in the 1972-73 Budget, on veterans' nursing care. This rose steadily to $30m in 1977-78 and to $58m in 1982-83. It is estimated that spending will rise to $64m on such health care in 1983-84. That will represent a 1,500 per cent increase in real terms over spending in 1972-73. That arises largely because the average age of veterans is now about 66. In those circumstances, large numbers of them are required to be accommodated in nursing homes on the basis of medical recommendations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has expressed concern, not just at the cost increases involved but because it has become apparent that a considerable number of persons in nursing homes would prefer to be kept in their own homes. So the Government has established a working party on aged care with a view to developing a system of aged care independence and to providing such financial resources as will enable persons to be kept in their own homes for longer periods. The evidence is that up to 30 per cent of nursing home residents could be more appropriately and more happily provided for and accommodated in the community in their own homes. This would make them happier. It would be a much more compassionate way of dealing with them, and there would be considerable savings to the community. In this light, the sort of increase to which I have referred has caused the Government to decide to establish an Office of Aged Care. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will have considerable influence in its establishment. The first part of that process occurred under the last Budget, when we established geriatric assessments units at each of the repatriation hospitals. Under the Commonwealth employment plan we have established a number of pilot schemes under which domiciliary help is being provided. I am hopeful that in the Budget that will be recognised as a permanent feature of the Department's activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is the Minister aware that there are two representatives of the European Economic Community in the chamber now and that they are in Australia to assess the Australian kangaroo industry? In light of this, I ask the Minister whether she can tell the Senate what steps the Government has taken to ensure that these gentlemen receive a fully balanced view of the industry. In particular, has the Government impressed on them the very strict conditions under which this industry is carried out in Australia and the severe adverse economic impact that cessation of imports of kangaroo products by the European Community would have on the Australian industry and our rural communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking on behalf of my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, I am aware that two members of the European Economic Community, Mr Eismar and Dr Jordan, are visiting Australia in order to discuss the entire kangaroo issue. From Senator Boswell's question, I understand that they are in the chamber at present. They will be meeting the Minister this afternoon. That will be an opportunity for frank discussion of the entire kangaroo issue, covering all of the matters to which Senator Boswell alluded in his question.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment will be making a major statement on the kangaroo issue next Monday. In his statement, the Minister is expected to cover a wide range of issues, from the establishment of a Federal kangaroo monitoring group to the inaccuracies that have been put forward by certain people with regard to kangaroo numbers and quotas. I understand that Senator Boswell is particularly interested in that last point-that there have been very many inaccuracies put around about the industry. I assure him that Mr Cohen will be addressing those problems in his statement on Monday, following his discussions with Mr Eismar and Dr Jordan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce . Is the Minister able to comment on the steel industry following the release of the recent report of the Steel Industry Authority? What has been the effect of the Government's steel industry plan on the industry's performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's initiatives in relation to the steel industry plan contained, in part, an important element which involved the appointment of a Steel Industry Authority to monitor the industry's performance and, particularly, the performance of the various contributors to the steel industry plan, namely, the producing companies, the trade unions and, of course, the Government, in another sense, in terms of bounty payments which were provided under the scheme. The Steel Industry Authority has recently published its report for the first quarter. It is an encouraging report.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to refer briefly to some of the matters that have emerged from that report and from recent statistics. The first point I would make is that annual production for the Australian steel industry is now running at approximately 6 million tonnes per year, which is close to the current maximum capacity of the industry. March quarter production for 1984 is 27 per cent above production for the equivalent quarter in 1983. The steel industry plan set a target from the companies and the unions in respect of productivity of 250 tonnes per man, and that target has been exceeded. The average productivity figure per man for the March quarter was 261 tonnes and that figure was probably adversely affected by the fact that the Newcastle steel making plant was out of operation for some time as a result of maintenance requirements. Employment in the steel division of the companies now stands at 24,214 compared with 26,091 in March 1983.

The Steel Industry Authority report also commented on the domestic steel market , the improvement in that market and a number of other matters which have emerged in the course of the first quarter of the operation of the plant. It is an encouraging start and the Government congratulates the trade unions involved and the producers on the willing way in which they have co-operated with the deliberations of the Steel Industry Authority. That co-operation will be of benefit not only to the steel industry but also to user industries and the whole of the Australian manufacturing industry sector. We very much welcome the approach which has been adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. When will the Sex Discrimination Act passed by the Parliament in March be proclaimed? Is its date of operation being delayed by difficulties in drafting the regulations? Has the Government selected an advertising agency to promote community understanding of the Act? If so, which agency has won the contract, how much is it worth and when will the campaign begin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first part of Senator Walters's question, no, the legislation is not being delayed by any difficulties in drafting regulations. We are waiting for the appointment of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner before we proclaim the Act. Indeed, there are regulations, but I am not aware of any drafting difficulties surrounding them. The position of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner was advertised two weeks ago, I think, and it is expected that a decision can be made fairly soon. Of course, the advertising of the Sex Discrimination Act is provided for in the legislation. Quite obviously the Government and all those people in the community who support this social reform want to be sure that people know how to take advantage of it and how to avail themselves of the protections which the Act provides. There is no point in making a social reform of this kind if the very people it is designed to help do not know of its existence or do not know how to go about using its provisions to get protection. So, as is provided for in the legislation, there will be a public education campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: Part of this public education campaign may well involve the use of an advertising agency to develop advertising of a kind, I suppose, that reaches more people than the kind of community education exercises which the Human Rights Commission is able to carry out. There has been some discussion by officers of the Office of the Status of Women with some advertising agencies, but any decision to employ an agency would be taken by the Government committee on advertising; it would not be taken just within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I think a meeting to discuss the possible use of an advertising agency in this campaign is scheduled for the near future, but no decision with respect to an advertising campaign using an agency has yet been taken. Discussions are in a preliminary stage and any amounts of money that might have been reported in the Press concerning the possible cost of such a campaign were, I imagine, invented by the people who wrote them, because no campaign is yet planned that could be costed in any precise way. As information on this becomes available, I will certainly be keeping the Senate and the public informed, because naturally there is a great deal of interest in the legislation and a great deal of keenness on the part of people in the community to make sure that they know how to get the benefit of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Can the Minister let me know whether tenders have been let for the advertising agency to be appointed? She did not answer the question: When will the campaign begin?

—To the best of my knowledge, tenders have not been let. There has been some discussion between the officers of the Office of the Status of Women and some advertising agencies about ways in which campaigns should be developed, but until we have a clear and agreed idea of the campaign the question of letting tenders is further down the track. To the best of my knowledge, no, tenders have not been let.

—I raise with the Attorney-General the statements he made in October last year following the report of a special working committee of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission chaired by Professor Ronald Sackville concerning the possibility of establishing a national compensation scheme. As it is Australian Labor Party policy to establish Australia's first national no- fault compensation scheme, has the Government decided on the form that that proposed scheme will take? Will this new system help create uniformity in compensation payments and eliminate the erratic differences in the amounts presently awarded by the courts? What stage has the Government reached in establishing this new scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Richardson says, as a party and now as a government we have made no secret of our commitment to accident compensation reform. Both the Labor Party's platform and our pre-election law and justice policy spell out our commitment to developing, in co-operation with the States, a national compensation scheme on a no-fault basis. The report of the Law Reform Commission chaired by Professor Sackville to which Senator Richardson referred was an interim report dealing with a no-fault compensation scheme for the victims of road accidents. It did not in its own terms deal with the national scheme, but the Government regarded it, and still regards it, as the best model yet developed to implement reforms in this area. The Government expects to be examining quite soon a submission prepared jointly by my Department, the Department of Social Security and the Treasury dealing with ways of introducing, on a co-operative basis with the States, a no-fault motor accident scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: Motorists around Australia will be only too conscious of the escalating costs of third party insurance premiums. Recent estimates suggest that car accidents cost the Australian community nationwide as much as $3,000m each year. A no- fault accident compensation scheme would compensate all victims of car accidents on a rational, humane and equitable basis, with periodic payments able to cover the costs and expenditure of a victim within a short time of an accident. That is in marked contrast to the erratic lottery which a victim of a car crash must engage in today, with lengthy and absurdly complex Supreme Court proceedings which may take up to three or four years to come to trial. When these cases finally come to judgment damages can vary dramatically and erratically.

Even worse, the present common law system concentrates on the behaviour of the person who causes the accident in determining whether the victim will be compensated. It regards the suffering and needs of the victim as secondary, whereas a no-fault system, honourable senators will be aware, concentrates on the sufferings of the victim and the victim's compensation needs. The Government has always stated that it sees the introduction of a comprehensive national compensation scheme as not something that can be unilaterally established by the Commonwealth. In that respect our perception differs from that of the previous Labor Government. We have said that we need a gradual, what we have called a four-phase, process of extensive consultation with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along the lines of the Senate Committee in 1975?

—That has some parallels. Considering the submission of a no-fault accident compensation scheme, which I referred to before, the Government will be thus embarking on at least its consideration of the first stage of establishing a national compensation scheme in all the areas to which I refer rather than just simply car accidents. However, I do not want, by anything I have just said, to create expectations that there will be any terribly early movement towards actual implementation on this. There are still formidable difficulties, of a financial and legal kind, in getting even just the accident transport scheme that we have in mind off the deck. However, we are working very hard at it. What I am endeavouring to do today is to give a progress statement that consideration by the Government of this is imminent and that we are at last setting a foot or two down the track.

ANSWER.PARA: The very last thing which I want to say and which I will say very quickly is that the humanity and efficiency of a no-fault scheme cannot be overestimated. It will benefit motorists, the public and those who suffer the tragic effects of the carnage on the road. There is a small but noisy group-lawyers-who believe that they will be disadvantaged by the restriction of common law actions. Over Easter I attended a legal conference in New Zealand and took the opportunity then to discuss the operation of the no fault system as it operates there. The situation is that New Zealand lawyers report that their practices are alive and well; there have been no bankruptcies and no impoverishment of New Zealand lawyers with their no fault compensation scheme. What has happened is that their work has expanded into other useful and profitable areas. I am sure that as a result of that the notorious capacity of lawyers to adapt themselves to changing environments, and always make a buck in the process, will ensure that they really have nothing to worry about with the scheme on which we are slowly but surely embarking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I point out that today there have been only nine questions and answers. In order to give every honourable senator a fair go at Question Time I plead with honourable senators to make their questions as short as possible, and likewise with Ministers in regard to their answers.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, and also in the Minister's capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. My question relates to the booklet published recently by the Institution of Engineers Australia, entitled ' Engineering Education in Crisis'. I ask: Will the Minister comment on the report 's claim that the present inadequate funding of engineering education and associated research and development is causing an erosion of the standards of engineering which will be detrimental to the economic development of Australia? In the light of the repeated statements made by the Government supporting the development of new high technology industries I ask the Minister, firstly, what role does the Government see for engineering education in the development of high technology enterprises and, secondly, will the Minister assure the Senate that adequate funding will be made available by the Government to professional engineering schools to ensure that they have sufficient staff, facilities and equipment to provide engineers skilled in the latest technology who are able to keep pace with the increasing rate of world technology progress?

—I am aware of Senator Missen's interest in engineering education. I say that in principle I endorse the sentiments about the importance of engineering education expressed in his question. I have had representations from engineering education interests.
—And there will be more, too.

—I am probably going to get some more from the Leader of the Government in the Senate. There is no doubt that there needs to be no concern in Senator Missen's mind that the Government is not aware both of the importance of the contribution engineering education can make and of the need for more co- ordination, indeed more resources in this area. I assure Senator Missen that this is something to which the Government is addressing itself. I have just received the first volume of the triennial report of the Tertiary Education Commission. That report will be available publicly in the next few days, as soon as it is printed. It addresses these matters. The Government will be making its response to the recommendations of the report in due course. Senator Missen sought some assurances about funds being forthcoming to meet all the needs of engineering education. Of course, Senator Missen will be aware that neither I nor any other Minister is in any position to give firm commitments about amounts of money. However, in the context of considering the recommendations of the Tertiary Education Commission for the development of the whole of the higher education and Technical and Further Education area in the forthcoming triennium, I assure him that the Government and I will be giving very serious attention to the needs and future development of engineering education.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health read the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations' report entitled, 'Deadly Neglect: Regulating the Manufacture of Therapeutic Goods' which claims that substandard medical devices are used by doctors in Australian hospitals because of lack of mandatory standards and inspections to enforce them? The report also claims that serious health problems have arisen regarding pharmaceutical products, including labelling errors and-
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to ask her question.

—Mr President, my next question is no longer than the last one. I continue, including labelling errors and contamination of sterile products. Can the Minister inform the Senate of what steps are being undertaken to ensure the adequate protection of health consumers through regulation of both medical equipment and pharmaceutical products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided me with a fairly lengthy response to Senator Zakharov's question. I think I can reassure Senator Zakharov that the concerns she has expressed in her question have been addressed. Mr President, in view of your previous remarks I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The Report in essence raises two major issues-the safety and efficacy of drugs and the quality control of drugs that are approved for marketing in Australia, and secondly, the safety and efficacy of devices which are currently in use in Australia.

In the case of drugs, controls exercised by my Department in collaboration with the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, ensure that new drugs are released only when the Committee is satisfied as to the safety and efficacy of such drugs . This assessment by the Committee is based on an independent review by my Department of the data supporting the quality, safety and efficacy of drugs and is acknowledged to be effective by world standards.

Continuing quality of drugs is ensured by a sampling programme as well as joint inspections of local manufacturers by officers of the National Biological Standards Laboratory and the State authority. While these programmes have proven effective the possibility of a breakdown quality control can still occur. It is my aim to have inspections at least annually.

In the case of devices, the AFCO report paid particular attention to the release of defective heart valves in Australia. At the present time, there is no independent review procedure for devices similar to that which applies to drugs. It is my view that such a review procedure should be introduced to minimise the possibility of releasing unsafe devices onto the Australian market. However, the magnitude of this problem is greater than that for drugs given that there are 3, 000 different types of devices and a total of a quarter of a million devices available in some overseas countries. It is my intention to initiate an independent review procedure for those devices which are to be used in a life saving situation or for which the Commonwealth Government has a significant financial commitment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I note that yesterday on the World Today program he referred to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the National Crime Authority legislation. The Attorney-General stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The great virtue of this Committee exercise has been that a lot of people have had a lot more time to understand what the nature of the organised crime problem is, the difficulties that confront executive governments right around Australia in dealing with it and the kind of really very elaborate legislative structure you need to cope with it.

Does the Attorney-General believe that that understanding that the Committee exercise has led to will extend to his colleagues, particularly in the Labor Caucus, who caused him so much trouble last year, in bringing forward 'any old form of crime authority', to use his own words? Does he now agree that he was wrong when he said in the Senate in the debate last year on the motion to refer the Bill to a committee that the delay in the establishment of the Authority which would result could not be justified.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to see that the pirate king is back on deck. If that reference is obscure, I remind honourable senators of the virtues of listening to Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Canberra occasionally.
—Order! I ask Senator Evans to answer the question.
—Senator Durack has been a bit land locked recently. I am glad to see the honourable senator is demonstrating signs of recovering his former swash and buckle.
—Order! I invite the Attorney-General to answer the question.

—Mr President, the question is so entirely lacking in substance that it entitles me to be a trifle playful in reply. The question is not one that can be addressed at all seriously. The reality of the matter is that the Government's commitment to the establishment of an effective national crime authority has been real, immediate and consistent over the whole period that we have been in office. The basic model that we have sought to establish is one that gets two balances right. These were conspicuously neglected in the activities of the previous Government in this respect. On the one hand there is the need to get right the balance between effective performance in dealing with organised crime and in responding to the very serious challenge that it creates while on the other hand at the same time not interfering unduly with individual liberties and getting appropriate checks and balances. The second balance that has to be got right is between the power and authority and capacity of the Commonwealth on the one hand and that of the States on the other hand. For a party which sitting on the Opposition benches has so traditionally prided itself on its commitment to the Australian Federation and to the desirability of co- operative federalism, there could not have been a greater debacle than the circumstances of its drafting and attempted introduction of its own national crime commission Bill, as it then was. The particular model that the present Government has sought continually to get into place, the elements of which have been confirmed and endorsed by the Senate Committee in its report, is a model that is addressed--

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, you have on a couple of occasions during Question Time made suggestions to both questioners and Ministers which have widespread agreement within the Senate. On this occasion we are getting a very lengthy address on matters which are not the subject matter of the question which was asked, and I ask you to bring the Minister to order.

—I cannot direct a Minister as to the manner in which he will answer a question; that is a matter for the Minister. I appeal to Ministers to make their answers as short as possible so that everyone in the Senate will get a fair go.

—I appreciate the force and good sense of that ruling, Mr President, and I shall not bore either you or the Senate very much longer. But it was a very boring question and I am entitled under those circumstances to give a boring answer. I finish it by saying that we are committed to a genuinely co-operative structure. Indeed, right now-I have been diverted from it by this Question Time-we are in the process downstairs--
—I thought it was because you were busy listening to local radio. Do you find it more interesting?

—Senator Rae's musical preferences would undoubtedly turn out to be for primitive music. I conclude by saying there has been a consistency of approach, which I think was the nub of Senator Durack's suggestion, in our attitude to the Crime Authority. We are concerned and anxious to get a workable body, and nothing that has happened over the course of the last few months gives the Government or me any ground whatsoever to acknowledge either error or the need for apology.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the criticism from the Opposition with reference to the method used by the Australian Statistician in establishing the consumer price index-
—Good question.

—Can the Minister, for my benefit and Senator Crowley's benefit, indicate the way in which the consumer price index is determined? Did the previous Government attempt to alter the way in which the consumer price index is calculated? Finally, has the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development objected in any way to the way in which Australia produces a consumer price index?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were several sub-questions and I will deal first with the last one. As far as I know the OEDC has not expressed any reservations about the way in which the Australian CPI is compiled, although I will ask the Treasurer for further information on that point. Senator Ray also asked whether the previous Government had attempted to make any changes. I think I can recall some minor changes being made during the term of the previous Government to the CPI or to its regimen, or at least to its weighting. I do not know whether that was done as a result of suggestions by the Government or spontaneously by the Australian Statistician. I will try to get that information as well. It is correct that the Australian CPI is not identical to the CPI used in other countries. One important difference between Australia and the United States of America, for example, is that interest rates are included in the American regimen and they are not included in the Australian regimen.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Ray asked whether the previous Government had attempted to make any changes. I think what he probably meant was any changes to the present CPI arrangements under which, effectively, indirect taxes are included in the CPI and direct taxes are not. I certainly cannot recall the previous Government attempting to change that arrangement. That has particular relevance to the Medicare levy and the negative quarterly March CPI figure. It is, of course, correct that the Medicare effect on the CPI will apply only in the March and June quarters. But it is still vital because with the wages policy that is in existence the Medicare effect, although it is a once only effect, will establish a new and lower threshold of inflation which will be sustained by the wages policy. For that reason it is very important. That is a fact which does not seem to have been appreciated by the Opposition-at least, if it is appreciated, it has refused to acknowledge it-nor has it been appreciated in the community as widely as it ought to have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is it a fact that on Wednesday last the Minister avoided answering a question as to what was the current position with the Government's plans for restructuring of industry? Was the subsequent report in yesterday's Australian Financial Review accurate in stating that the Government has criticised the draft report of the special task force on industry restructuring because the report did not sufficiently reflect the Government's policy on restructuring? Will the Minister now answer the question as to the current state of progress of the Government's plans for industry restructuring?

—There is a certain confusion in the question, about which I must say I am not surprised. But the question I was asked earlier was about a meeting of the Parliamentary Labor Party committee on industry policy.
—The question asked: 'Will the Minister indicate to the Senate the current position?'.

—But that is not the point of the honourable senator's question. The point of his question related to what I answered in the Senate the other day . In answering a question in the Senate the other day I was answering a question about what I said, and the reaction to what I said, in the Caucus industry policy committee. I answered that question. If Senator Rae wishes to confuse that with the committee of public servants which has been working on this question in relation to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, he is at liberty to do so. But the confusion will not help him or anybody else. Insofar as the committee of officials is concerned, there was a difference in terms of the approach adopted by that committee and by me. But that is inevitable and, indeed , it is desirable that there should be a dynamic discussion about these matters in developing an approach to industry policy. I am now asked by Senator Rae whether I will provide an answer in relation to the Government's policy on industry restructuring.
—The current state of progress.

—If he wants information on the current state of progress, this matter is being considered by various departments-predominantly my Department- and various groups of officials. It is being considered by a committee of Ministers and, of course, it is being considered by me. But when one talks about restructuring of industry, I hope it is recognised that that is a continuing and ongoing process. It would be absurd to bring down some sort of blueprint or statement of that kind in relation to a question such as this. The progress which the honourable senator asked about is being reflected in the work of those various bodies to which I referred. Ultimately the implementation of those deliberations must be seen in relation to a number of specific areas of industry policy in a pragmatic way as events occur from time to time. But that is the state of progress in respect of which I was asked to comment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister refer to page 1478 of the Hansard of 2 May 1984 and then make a statement to the Senate indicating that he was wrong when he accused me a few moments ago of referring to a question which was not the question asked last Wednesday? That question-the same reference that I made today-was:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister indicate to the Senate the current position of the Government 's plans on industry restructuring?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I will not do that because the honourable senator is so confused that he does not even know which confusions he is involved in at this stage. If he spends the next week reading copies of Hansard and asks me another question about it, I will try to answer his question then.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. As the very existence of the Department of Veterans' Affairs arises out of the need to look after people who have returned from wars, is it planning to make any contribution to the International Year of Peace in 1986?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has written to all departments suggesting that they should make a contribution to the International Year of Peace in 1986. I am sure that each department will consider this very seriously. My Department has, and it is planning to make a positive contribution in conjunction with the Department of Foreign Affairs. I have written to the Minister and advised him in those terms. I proposed a number of initiatives in that letter. The first was a scheme to train doctors and other technicians from South East Asian countries in respect of our Repatriation Artificial Limb and Appliances Centre. That is particularly important having regard to the amounts of civil strife that exists in countries north of Australia. The second initiative was to consider establishing 'Gardens of Peace' and 'Peace Playgrounds' at our Repatriation general hospitals, and the third was to mount mobile peace displays at agricultural shows, libraries, art galleries and museums. The fourth initiative was to assist the Department of Foreign Affairs in producing a peace film by providing information about the voluntary work of ex-service organisations.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is most important that my Department play a significant role in the decision of the United Nations to conduct a year of peace in 1986, particularly because the clients of the Department of Veterans' Affairs are veterans and casualties of war and are in the best position to realise the need to carry out the prime objectives of the United Nations as stated in its charter 'to save succeeding generations from the ravages of war and instead, to practise tolerance and live together to maintain international peace and security'. I am certain that they are the sentiments of the overwhelming majority of veterans in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It relates to those hundreds of thousands of unemployed Australians who comprised the one major group who have continued to suffer from the policies of this Government and all State governments. In view of the Government's claim that the economy is improving dramatically, will the Government use its influence to negotiate with State governments for the immediate elimination of the iniquitous anti-employment tax, the States payroll taxes, from all 1984-85 Budgets?

—The Government has been very conscious in determining its macroeconomic policies of the plight of unemployed people in Australia. I just remind the honourable senator in relation to the earlier parts of his question that the Government, prior to the 1983 election, made it quite clear that in its view the capacity to reduce unemployment at the rate at which he would have liked was severely limited. But, in spite of that, there has been a significant reduction in unemployment and as well a significant increase in the rate of job creation in Australia, a much better outcome than the Government expected. The honourable senator asked me more specifically about the question of payroll tax. Certainly we are aware, as governments throughout Australia ought to be aware, of the possible adverse effects or likely adverse effects of the payroll tax on employment. I understand that it is a matter which has been discussed at the Economic Planning Advisory Council. I regard it as a matter which has to be attended to as soon as possible. But I of course can make no commitments on behalf of this Government at this stage in relation to budgetary deliberations and outcomes. I am grateful to the honourable senator for drawing my attention again to this important consideration.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Cocos and Christmas Islands-Increased Air Fares

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ELECTORATE: (Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It being two minutes to one, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
I do so to enable Estimates committees to meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. The decision by the Federal Labor Government to include the Cocos and Christmas Island groups with the Northern Territory for voting and referenda purposes poses a number of important questions for the future status of the Northern Territory. As honourable senators will be aware, the Northern Territory attained self-government in 1978. Since then, it has been progressing toward statehood and is now at a stage where there is a glimmer of light at the end of the tunnel . However, the decision to include Cocos and Christmas Islands could raise some difficulties. It is said that these islands could not be included with Western Australia despite their strong trade and communication links because, under the Australian Constitution, a State's boundaries cannot be extended to take in a Territory. No doubt this could be corrected by referendum. If this is not done, to overcome future problems once the Northern Territory gains statehood, the Cocos and Christmas Islands would surely have to be divested from the Northern Territory. Why then should the Federal Labor Government's proposals to include the islands with the Northern Territory in the interim period be carried out in the first place?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me there are very many legal questions relating to States and Territories that require review before any action on this matter is taken. The rights of the Northern Territory and its people must be protected, and the Federal Government should also be seeking a suitable answer to ensure that the people of Cocos and Christmas Islands, and for that matter perhaps Norfolk Island, are given the right to vote in Federal elections and referenda. Rather than rushing into this matter, I suggest to the Government that much more consideration be given to this very important decision concerning representation for the people on these islands. As I have said before, we must also consider the future of the Northern Territory.

In closing, I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) who represents the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the Senate to answer the following questions when he is in a position to do so: Does the Government intend to go ahead with its proposals to include the Cocos and Christmas Islands with the Northern Territory electorate for the purposes of voting in Federal elections and referenda? If so, will the Government allow the Northern Territory to attain statehood at a time when the Territory Government and its people feel that this is appropriate? What then will be the status of the Cocos and Christmas Islands? Would they be included with the Northern Territory as part of the new State which of course does not appear to be possible under the Constitution? If not, what does the Government envisage their future to be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 3 April this year during Question Time I asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) who represents the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) about an increase in air fares which had been announced the previous day. The Hansard record of that question reads as follows :

SPEECH.PARA: I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Has the Independent Air Fares Committee presented a detailed report on its reasons for recommending a 2 per cent increase in air fares on 2 April? If so, is that report publicly available? If not, will a report be made available so that the travelling public and elected representatives are able to scrutinise the Committee's assessment?

In reply the Minister for Veterans' Affairs informed me that not only is the Independent Air Fares Committee obliged to publish its findings following a fare review, but also it is required to make available the evidence and reasons for its conclusions. The Committee must have published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette a notice setting out the terms of the determination, the reason for making it and any findings or facts placed before it. At the time I asked the question, the Independent Air Fares Committee had not published its findings. These findings have now been gazetted and may be found in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. G 16, dated 24 April. I do not wish to read the gazettal notice, but I consider it essential to my comments. I therefore seek leave to have the gazettal notice incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The notice read as follows-
SPECIAL INFORMATION
NOTICES UNDER THE INDEPENDENT AIR FARES COMMITTEE ACT 1981
DETERMINATION
Operator: Ansett Airlines of Australia-Trans Australian Airlines.
Section of Act: 15.
Date notified: 29 March 1984.
Brief particulars of terms and reasons: In response to a request from one of the above operators, the Committee undertook a major air fares review and on 29 March 1984 determined as follows:
Economy Air Fare Formulae
Determination of the following formulae for setting economy air fares over related routes operated by Ansett Airlines of Australia (AAA) and Trans Australia Airlines (TAA), effective 2 April 1984.
Jet Services:
The formula for AAA and TAA jet services incorporating a flag-fall plus a distance rate will be:
Fare ($) = A + BX + CX2 + DX3 where:
A is the flag-fall (value 44.40)
B, C, D are the distance coefficients (values B = 143.35; C = -20.64; D = 1.71)
X is the journey distance expressed in thousands of kilometres
For multistage journeys, the distance rate for kilometres in excess of 3611, where applicable, will be calculated at 6.118 cents per kilometre.
This determination results in an increase of 2% for the jet air fare formula.
F27 Services:
The formula for AAA and TAA F27 services incorporating a flag-fall plus a distance rate will be:
Fare ($) = A + BX where
A is the flag-fall (value 44.7)
B is the distance coefficient (value 0.14585)
X is the journey distance in kilometres.
This determination is the same as that determined by the Committee on 29 September 1983.
Through Fares

The Committee determined that, where the sum of sector fares does not apply, a sum of $5 be added to the through fare to reduce the amount being absorbed by an airline when constructing a through fare with another operator, except in certain instances where a specific arrangement has been approved by the Committee.
Each operator sought fare increases for jet and F27 services substantially in excess of that approved, and submitted that such increases would have little effect on demand.

As required, AAA and TAA provided detailed and extensive operational and financial data including revised cost and revenue estimates for the 1983/84 financial year. The Committee also had regard to its Cost Allocation Reviews Report of 13 August 1982 and to information provided by both operators for their last (September 1983) major air fares review.

The revised estimates submitted by both operators showed increases in costs generally (including provision for wage increases effective April 1984) offset by improvements in traffic and revenue yields, and lower unit costs resulting from the impact of the cost reduction programs implemented by both airlines.

Aircraft utilisation, in particular for wide-bodied aircraft, is generally not at levels the Committee would regard as efficient. This reflects the composition and size of both operator's aircraft fleets which do not enable the airlines to efficiently service the present market.

The Committee was pleased to note the continuing improvements being made by both operators in efficiency generally but from its examination of a number of measures formed the view that there were still certain areas in which further gains could be made.

The estimated profit levels of AAA and TAA for the current financial year as assessed by the Committee were likely to show an improvement on the levels estimated at the last major review. Nevertheless, the estimated profit returns for the 1983/84 financial year, including increased revenue from the 2% increase , were regarded by the operators as inadequate. The Committee concluded that the profit levels were constrained by the less than efficient use of the airline's resources, in particular aircraft and through the current state of passenger demand.
The Committee further concluded that an increase in air fares of the extent sought by the operators could have a material and detrimental impact on demand.

Having regard to the evidence and material before it, including the level of operating costs likely to be incurred by the airlines to the end of the 1983/84 financial year, the Committee determined that a 2% increase in the jet air fare formula for AAA and TAA was justified and appropriate.
The Committee further determined that no increase was justified or appropriate in AAA's and TAA's F27 air fare formula having regard to the cost structure and efficiency of these operations.
The 2% increase in jet air fares approved for AAA and TAA will mean a compounded cumulative increase of 9.5% for 1983/84 and represents the lowest increase in a financial year since 1977/78.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It will be recalled that in my question on 3 April, I asked whether a report would be made available 'so that the travelling public and elected representatives are able to scrutinise the Committee's assessment'. For that purpose, the Independent Air Fares Committee report is useless. It begins by outlining that the Committee undertook a review of air fares in response to a request from one of the major airline operators, Ansett Airlines of Australia or Trans Australia Airlines. It may be inferred from the Committee's comment that either Ansett or TAA did not seek a fare increase. The gazettal notice then refers to some complicated formulae by which fares are to be calculated. No explanation of how these formulae were arrived at is given. The remainder of the notice is a self-justification for increasing fares by 2 per cent with very little, if any, hard data to support the increase. One of the paragraphs of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The revised estimates submitted by both operators showed increases in costs generally (including provision for wage increases effective April 1984) offset by improvements in traffic and revenue yields, and lower unit costs resulting from the impact of the cost reduction programs implemented by both airlines.

One of the cost increases was stated to be wage increases. Wage increases are always a convenient excuse. I would like to ask: What were the increases in costs generally? What did the airlines' submissions say in relation to wage increases? What were the offsets? The whole of the paragraph above is double talk. It provides no information by which this Committee's determination can be verified or refuted. One further paragraph states:

Having regard to the evidence and material before it, including the level of operating costs likely to be incurred by the airlines to the end of the 1983/84 financial year, the Committee determined that a 2 per cent increase in the jet air fare formula for AAA and TAA was justified and appropriate.

The evidence and material before the Committee should be available to the public and their representatives. I cannot accept that the increase as determined by the Committee is justified; neither can the travelling public.

Air travel is used extensively throughout Australia because of the long distances between major cities in our country. In Queensland, the State that I represent in this place, air travel is essential for many people. Queensland is the most decentralised of the States. Any increases in air fares are a blow to those residents of Queensland who have to travel long distances. I could, as well, mention the viability of Queensland's tourist industry; an industry which is the second largest in Queensland and has a high labour content. From Coolangatta to the Papua New Guinea border, an estimated 100,000 people are employed in the tourist industry. The industry itself injects approximately $2. 23 billion annually into the Queensland economy. Any increases in air fares are counter-productive to the efforts made in Queensland to maintain, and even increase, the tourist traffic to the State.

I acknowledge that, from time to time, increases in air fares will be justified . But the public and the public's elected representatives should be able to see that the increases are justified. They cannot do so at present and have to take the Independent Air Fares Committee's determination on trust. I am not prepared to do that. The Committee must provide that data which will enable its conclusions to be put to the test. I call on the Committee to do that in future. If it does not, it may be necessary to have a close look at the Independent Air Fares Committee Act to determine whether legislative amendments are necessary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the current arrangements regarding foreign ownership of Australian uranium projects.
(2) Do all projects currently satisfy these guidelines.
(3) What percentages of Australian uranium resources are currently owned by overseas interests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Treasurer announced on 20 December 1983 that the Government has decided to defer consideration of foreign investment policy applying to proposals involving the mining, production and enrichment of uranium until after the Australian Science and Technology Council inquiry into issues relating to Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle. In the meantime the broad thrust of foreign investment policy first elaborated by the previous Labor Government in 1975 and, with some amendment in the light of changing circumstances, maintained by the previous Government, will be continued.

(2) The Government's uranium policy provides only for operations for the recovery of uranium at the existing Ranger and Nabarlek mines and at the proposed Olympic Dam project in South Australia, if the joint venturers take a commercial decision to proceed with that project. Those projects had received foreign investment approval under the guidelines established by the previous Government. The Ranger project has 75 per cent Australian equity and the Nabarlek project is 100 per cent Australian owned. The foreign investment arrangements for the Olympic Dam project were approved with Australian equity of 51 per cent it being recognised that Olympic Dam was not exclusively a uranium project. The basis of the approval was set out in the then Acting Treasurer's statement of 9 October 1979.

(3) Central to the question of the level of overseas ownership in uranium resources is that the Government policy only provides for the export of uranium from the existing Nabarlek and Ranger mines and the Olympic Dam project, if the joint venturers decide to proceed with that project. The equity for those projects is given in (2).

In relation to exploration, overseas interests involved in such activities in Australia searching for minerals, including uranium, are not required to seek approval under foreign investment policy to take up an exploration licence. Exploration licences do not convey ownership of minerals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the specific elements of the steel industry plan which make a ' fast track' anti-dumping mechanism appropriate.
(2) What is the reason(s) why a 'fast track' anti-dumping mechanism is not appropriate to any other industry (see Hansard, answer to Question No. 340, page 2603).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The steel industry plan is unique in that it involves commitments by the steel industry, the steel unions and the Government. The major producer, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, has undertaken to continue the operation of the integrated steel plants at Newcastle, Port Kembla and Whyalla and to provide job security for the period of the plan. The Company is also committed to an investment plan involving expenditure of up to $800m over a four-year period.

Given the frequency of allegations of dumping and the absence of qualitative restrictions on steel imports, the Australian producer needs reasonable assurances that the investment program would not be put at risk by imports at less than fair market prices.

The Steel Industry Authority, through its detailed and continuous monitoring of overseas and domestic steel prices, will make a 'fast track' dumping mechanism possible-by providing expeditious gathering and analysis of relevant data from the local steel industry and importers.

The immediate availability of this information will facilitate the reaching of a preliminary finding on complaints involving alleged dumping of steel imports well within the prescribed period of 45 days which apply in the case of other dumping complaints.
The dumping of goods in Australia, regardless the commodity, is of a major concern to this government.

As a demonstration of that concern, shortly after the government came to office it directed an immediate review of both the legislation and the procedures for investigating dumping and subsidisation complaints.
On 7 November last year, as a result of that review, I announced that the investigation of all dumping and subsidisation complaints was to be speeded up.

Unless there are exceptional or complex circumstances a preliminary finding of whether injurious dumping or subsidisation exists will be reached within 45 days of the complaint being accepted by the department. If the preliminary finding is positive the investigation will then be finalised within a further 120 days.
At the preliminary finding stage, if a threat of injury from future dumped or subsidised imports is apparent, provisional action against these imports can be taken.
These procedures which will ensure a speedy resolution of dumping or subsidisation complaints will apply to all complaints regardless the commodity or the source of the goods.

The Council, which comprised representatives of manufacturers, unions, retailers, importers, consumers and the Government, was meeting primarily to discuss the draft report of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee (Elix Committee) prior to that report being forwarded to the Government for consideration. It was in the context of discussions on the draft report, including various aspects of the tender quota arrangements, that the request for a 'summit' was made.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Army Firing Range: Shire of Cobar

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Moomba- Sydney pipeline traverses about 150 kilometres of the proposed area.

The Pipeline Authority has been briefed on the proposal and has received assurances concerning the positioning of the impact zones and the safety of the pipeline. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 April 1984 (Hansard, page 1292) Senator Elstob asked me, as Minister representing the Special Minister of State, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister advise whether the current study (into simplifying government departmental forms) also applies to departmental information brochures? Will the Minister consider extending the expertise gained from this study to future government information and advertising campaigns?
The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The simpler forms program is concerned primarily with administrative forms used by members of the public. Information materials such as brochures and other publications are the focus of our plain English program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1984 Senator Sir John Carrick asked me a question without notice (Hansard, page 1012) concerning the Four Corners program on uranium. I said I would consider making a statement outlining my views on the program.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say at the outset that the effectiveness of international safeguards arrangements and Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements is one of the matters being examined by the Australian Science and Technology Council. Inquiry into aspects of Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle. The inquiry is due to report this month and the Government will be considering what specific action it needs to take in this area in the light of that report. With that inquiry in progress I do not wish to make a detailed statement on safeguards matters. However, there were some factual points in the Four Corners program which I believe should be corrected. Overall, I must say I found the program disappointing, in that it made no real effort to inform viewers of exactly what safeguards techniques involve and to explain the objectives and goals of safeguards measures.

Any evaluation of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and the safeguards system should be made against a knowledge of the aims of the system and its capabilities. It must be made clear that the major objectives of the system are: to provide assurance to the international community by verification that states are complying with their non-proliferation and 'peaceful use' undertakings; and to deter the diversion of safeguarded nuclear materials or the misuse of safeguarded facilities for the production of nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. Deterrence is aimed at dissuading, by the risk of detection, any state that might contemplate diversion of nuclear materials or the misuse of nuclear facilities. Thus safeguards must be technically capable, and seen to be capable, of promptly detecting any diversion so that the international community can be alerted to take appropriate action.

The safeguards system is not perfect but methods and techniques are being improved all the time. The record of the IAEA is very good, as is evidenced by the fact that since the commencement of IAEA safeguards no diversion of any safeguarded material has been recorded. I would suggest that any danger of proliferation of nuclear weapons would arise from sensitive facilities which are not under safeguards rather than from the operation of safeguarded facilities, hence the importance of seeking universal acceptance of safeguards arrangements. The Four Corners program claimed that the concept of 'Australian uranium' becomes virtually meaningless from the conversion stage because Australian origin nuclear material (AONM) is mingled with uranium from other sources.

The mingling of uranium from various sources is the normal practice through the international nuclear fuel cycle, and hence national attribution is accorded to particular quantities on an equivalence and proportional basis. This is a well established approach in a number of domestic and international commodity areas, e.g. minerals and grains. A rough analogy might be drawn with banking: We do not expect to withdraw the very same notes and coins as we have previously deposited , but we do ensure that the value is the same. In the same way we are concerned to ensure that the requisite quantities of nuclear material are confined to peaceful, non-explosive uses.

The Four Corners program noted that the enrichment plant at Oak Ridge in the United States is not subject to IAEA inspections, and one interviewee said that the IAEA has no safeguards involvement with this plant. Another interviewee claimed there were no safeguards because Australia had not insisted on them. Neither of these interviewees was correct. Australia requires all AONM to be subject to IAEA safeguards. As the Oak Ridge enrichment facility is not subject to IAEA inspection, Australia has concluded an arrangement with the United States and the IAEA whereby the IAEA has constructed a Material Balance Area around the facility to verify that the same quantity of AONM leaves the plant as initially entered it, thus ensuring that AONM remains in peaceful, non-explosive use.

The supposed absence of safeguards on yellowcake was touched on a number of times. In particular, it was said that international safeguards do not apply while uranium is at sea, and that there is no confirmation that material received corresponds to material shipped.

It is correct that the IAEA does not conduct inspections at the yellowcake stage, reflecting the assessment that with the low strategic value of yellowcake and the comparatively ready availability of uranium it would be inappropriate to divert inspection resources from more strategically significant nuclear fuel cycle activities. However, the IAEA does require notification of quantities shipped and received, so that there is confirmation of receivals. Moreover, Australia's own safeguards requirements apply to yellowcake. Responsibilities for such matters as physical protection in transit are required to be established between Australia and the Government of the receiving country, which is also required to confirm to Australian authorities (the Australian Safeguards Office) the quantities of yellowcake received. Those quantities are then checked against Australian records of quantities shipped.

Reference to the alleged disappearance of a yellowcake shipment in 1968 is of limited relevance to the question of the adequacy of safeguards now, as that incident predated the present international safeguards regime, (including the bilateral requirements for physical protection referred to above.

Australia has signed the International Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, which will significantly strengthen arrangements applying to the international transport of uranium. I note that although the Four Corners team filmed the signing ceremony in Vienna on 21 February, and this was actually shown in the background at one point in the program, the commentary made no reference whatsoever to the Convention.

The program asserted that owing to the present uranium over-supply situation Australia would have little influence on international safeguards by being in the market. Australia is seen as a stable and reliable supplier and many countries are prepared to buy from us, for example for reasons of diversity of supply, in spite of the market situation. To the extent that Australia secures, and has secured in the past, sales with stringent conditions attached, there is clearly a positive effect on the proportion of material in the international fuel cycle subject to safeguards restrictions. If Australia were to withdraw from the market this benefit would be lost.

The program referred to the Federal Republic of Germany (FRG) having consent to reprocess AONM. In the case of four agreements-with EURATOM (which includes FRG) , France, Sweden and Japan-Australia has agreed conditions under which it has exercised its consent in advance and on a long term basis to reprocessing where the reprocessing is to take place in a nuclear fuel cycle program agreed with Australia, under IAEA safeguards, and for the purpose of energy use of spent fuel management. As in other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle, all AONM going into and coming out of a reprocessing plant must be fully accounted for. This means that AONM cannot contribute to any stock or nuclear material not under safeguards.

Even if the Four Corners presentation had been accurate and objective, the conclusion apparently reached by some people that it established a case for withholding Australian uranium is illfounded. Given that there are several alternative suppliers, how an embargo on Australian exports would reduce the dangers of proliferation is a matter for wide-eyed conjecture before and after the Four Corners program. Considering that some alternative suppliers will impose few if any supply conditions, an Australian withdrawal is more likely to increase the dangers. This is both a very important and a very complex area, where the public is entitled to adequate factual details to facilitate informed debate. I would expect that the report of the ASTEC inquiry will make a major contribution in this regard.
